The morning sun cast long shadows across the cobblestone streets of Frankfurt's old quarter as Klaus Zimmermann adjusted his military dress uniform for what felt like the hundredth time. His calloused hands, more accustomed to gripping a rifle than smoothing fabric, trembled slightly as he straightened the crisp collar. Today was different from any other day in his twenty-eight years of life, different from the countless mornings he'd spent in barracks or on patrol. Today, Klaus would dance.

"Mein Gott, you look like you're about to face a firing squad rather than a ballroom," chuckled his roommate Heinrich from across their modest apartment. Heinrich was sprawled carelessly across his unmade bed, still in yesterday's clothes, a half-empty bottle of beer dangling from his fingers despite the early hour. The contrast between the two men couldn't have been starker – Klaus, immaculate and nervous, Heinrich, disheveled and perpetually relaxed.

"It feels almost the same," Klaus replied, his voice carrying the slight rasp that came from years of shouting orders across training grounds. He moved to the small mirror hanging crooked on the wall, a relic from the apartment's previous tenant. The reflection that stared back at him was familiar yet somehow foreign. The same angular jawline, the same steel-gray eyes that had seen too much during his tours of duty, but there was something else there now – hope, perhaps, or maybe just barely contained terror.

Heinrich rolled his eyes and took another swig of beer. "You do realize this is supposed to be fun, yes? Dancing, music, pretty women in sparkly dresses? Not exactly a combat mission." He paused, studying his friend's rigid posture. "When was the last time you did something just because it made you happy?"

The question hung in the air like smoke from Heinrich's ever-present cigarettes. Klaus couldn't remember the last time he'd done anything purely for joy. His life had been structured, regimented, purposeful in the way military life demanded. Wake at five, physical training at six, duties until evening, sleep by ten. Repeat. The dancing lessons had started almost by accident – a wrong turn down a Frankfurt street three months ago had led him past Studio Harmony, where Frau Elisabeth Steinberg taught ballroom dancing to anyone brave enough to step through her doors.

"I should have practiced the foxtrot more," Klaus muttered, ignoring Heinrich's philosophical question. He began pacing the small confines of their living room, his polished boots clicking rhythmically against the worn wooden floors. "The judges will be watching every step, every turn. One mistake and—"

"And what?" Heinrich interrupted, sitting up with more energy than he'd shown all morning. "The world ends? You get court-martialed for poor heel-toe technique?" He shook his head in amazement. "Klaus, my friend, you've survived three deployments, earned two commendations for bravery, and you're worried about dancing?"

But Klaus wasn't listening anymore. His mind had drifted to the letter he'd received two weeks prior, the letter that had changed everything. The Frankfurt Municipal Dance Competition Committee had written to inform him that he'd been selected as one of twenty finalists for their annual championship. Twenty finalists from over three hundred applicants. The letter was carefully folded in his breast pocket now, read and reread so many times the creases had become permanent.

The selection had shocked everyone, including Klaus himself. He'd entered the preliminary competition on a whim, encouraged by Frau Steinberg who insisted he had "natural rhythm hiding beneath all that military stiffness." She'd been teaching him for only two months when the preliminaries were announced, hardly enough time to master anything beyond the basic steps. Yet somehow, dancing with Greta Müller, a secretary from the mayor's office who'd become his regular partner, he'd managed to impress the judges enough to advance.

"She'll be there today," Klaus said suddenly, stopping his pacing to look out the window toward the city center where the competition would be held.

"Who? Greta?" Heinrich asked, though he already knew the answer. Klaus had talked about little else for weeks. Greta with her auburn hair that caught the light when she spun. Greta with her patient smile when he stumbled through a difficult sequence. Greta who somehow made the regimented soldier feel graceful, almost elegant.

"She's been so patient with me," Klaus continued, his voice softening. "Never complains when I step on her feet, never laughs when I lose count of the music. She says I'm getting better, but..." He trailed off, uncertainty creeping back into his voice.

Heinrich stood and walked over to his friend, placing a hand on his shoulder. "But nothing. You earned your place in that final fair and square. Stop acting like you don't deserve to be there." He paused, studying Klaus's profile as he continued staring out the window. "You know what your problem is? You think everything has to be perfect, that you have to be the best at everything you try. Sometimes it's okay to just... be."

The words struck something deep in Klaus's chest, though he couldn't quite identify what. All his life had been about excelling, about meeting standards and exceeding expectations. In the military, mediocrity could mean death – for himself or his men. But dancing? Dancing was supposed to be different, wasn't it? Yet here he was, treating it like another mission to complete, another objective to achieve.

A church bell chimed in the distance, and Klaus felt his stomach lurch. "I should go," he said, though his feet seemed rooted to the floor. "The competition starts in two hours, and I promised Greta I'd meet her early for a final practice session."

"Go then," Heinrich said, returning to his bed and his beer. "And Klaus? Try to smile out there. You're allowed to enjoy this."

Klaus nodded, grabbed his jacket, and headed for the door. As his hand touched the handle, Heinrich called out once more: "Whatever happens today, you're still the same man who pulled three wounded soldiers to safety under enemy fire. A dancing competition should be easy compared to that."

But as Klaus stepped into the morning sunlight and began walking toward the city center, he wasn't so sure. Combat he understood – there were rules, tactics, clear objectives. Dancing felt like stepping into uncharted territory, where success couldn't be measured in tactical victories or completed missions. It was messier, more uncertain, more human.

The streets of Frankfurt were already bustling with early morning activity. Shopkeepers swept their storefronts, early commuters hurried past with newspapers tucked under their arms, and somewhere in the distance, Klaus could hear the faint sound of music drifting from an open window. The city felt alive in a way he rarely noticed during his usual routine of base duties and military obligations.

As he walked, Klaus found himself thinking about the path that had led him to this moment. Three months ago, he'd been a soldier and nothing more. His identity was wrapped up entirely in his rank, his duties, his service record. Now, incredibly, he was also a dancer – or at least someone who danced. The transformation felt both thrilling and terrifying.

The studio where he'd first met Frau Steinberg came into view, its windows still dark at this early hour. But Klaus could picture it as it would be later in the day, filled with couples moving in perfect synchronization, the sound of feet gliding across polished floors, the gentle guidance of Frau Steinberg's voice calling out instructions and encouragement.

She had been the one to suggest he enter the preliminary competition, despite his protests that he wasn't ready. "Readiness is a luxury," she'd said in her matter-of-fact way. "Sometimes you must simply begin." At the time, he'd thought she was talking about dancing. Now he wondered if she'd meant something else entirely.The venue for the Frankfurt Municipal Dance Competition was the Grand Ballroom of the Kaiserhof Hotel, a magnificent space that Klaus had only glimpsed from the street during his years stationed in the city. As he approached the imposing limestone facade, with its ornate carvings and tall windows that reflected the morning light like mirrors, he felt his breath catch in his throat. The building seemed to dwarf him, its grandeur a stark reminder of how far he'd traveled from his humble beginnings in a small Bavarian village where the grandest social event had been the annual harvest festival in the local church hall.

Couples were already arriving, their practice bags slung over shoulders, some stretching against the hotel's exterior walls while others ran through quick sequences on the sidewalk. Klaus recognized several faces from the preliminary rounds – there was Herr Mueller, a bank manager who danced with his wife of thirty years, their movements so synchronized they seemed to share a single heartbeat. Near the entrance, he spotted the young couple from Munich whose tango had left the preliminary judges speechless, their dark hair and matching black practice outfits making them look like professional performers rather than amateur competitors.

The sight of such seasoned pairs made Klaus's confidence waver again. These people had clearly been dancing together for years, their partnerships refined through countless hours of practice and performance. What was he doing here, a soldier who had learned to waltz only months ago, presuming to compete against such established talent? His hands found the letter in his breast pocket again, touching it as if to reassure himself that his invitation wasn't some elaborate mistake or cruel joke.

"Klaus! There you are!" The familiar voice cut through his spiraling doubts like a lifeline. Greta emerged from the hotel's revolving door, her auburn hair pinned up in an elegant chignon that made her neck look impossibly graceful. She wore a simple blue dress that would later be replaced by their competition gown, but even in practice clothes, she moved with the fluid confidence that had first caught his attention in Frau Steinberg's studio. Her smile was warm and genuine, free from the nervous energy that seemed to radiate from every other competitor in sight.

"You look like you're planning a military strategy rather than preparing for a dance," she teased gently, falling into step beside him as they walked toward the hotel entrance. Her presence immediately steadied him, the way it always did. There was something about Greta that made the world feel more manageable, less overwhelming. Perhaps it was her background as a secretary – she was accustomed to bringing order to chaos, to finding solutions for seemingly impossible problems. Or perhaps it was simply her nature, calm and assured where he was anxious and uncertain.

The hotel lobby was a marvel of marble and crystal, with soaring ceilings decorated in gold leaf and a chandelier that cast rainbow fragments across the polished floors. Klaus had to consciously prevent himself from gawking like a tourist as they made their way toward the ballroom. The wealth displayed here so casually was more than his family had seen in their entire lives, more luxury than existed in all the barracks where he'd spent the better part of a decade. He felt simultaneously grateful for the opportunity to experience such grandeur and acutely aware of how out of place he was in this rarefied world.

Other competitors filled the lobby, their conversations creating a low buzz of excitement and nervous energy. Klaus caught fragments of discussion about technique and strategy, about judges' preferences and scoring systems. The level of sophistication in these conversations made him realize how much he still didn't know about the world of competitive dancing. He and Greta had focused on learning the steps, mastering the basic techniques, but these people spoke of dancing as if it were a science, with theories and methodologies that went far beyond simple choreography.

"Stop overthinking," Greta whispered, apparently reading his expression as easily as she might read one of the reports that crossed her desk at city hall. "Remember what Frau Steinberg always tells us – dancing is feeling first, thinking second. All those people talking strategy? Half of them will forget everything they've planned the moment the music starts." Her hand brushed against his arm reassuringly, and Klaus felt some of the tension leave his shoulders.

The ballroom itself was even more magnificent than Klaus had imagined. The ceiling soared at least thirty feet above the polished parquet floor, supported by columns wrapped in gold leaf that caught and reflected the light from three massive chandeliers. Tall windows lined one wall, offering glimpses of Frankfurt's skyline, while the opposite wall featured ornate mirrors that made the already enormous space seem infinite. A raised platform at one end of the room held chairs for the judges, while another platform accommodated the orchestra that would provide live music for the competition.

Tables and chairs had been arranged around the perimeter of the dance floor for spectators, and Klaus was surprised to see that many were already occupied despite the early hour. He recognized some faces from the preliminary competition – family members, friends, and what appeared to be serious dance enthusiasts who attended such events regularly. The sight of the audience made his stomach clench again. Dancing with Greta in the relative privacy of Frau Steinberg's studio was one thing; performing in front of hundreds of strangers was something else entirely.

"The floor is beautiful," Greta observed, kneeling to run her hand across the smooth parquet. "Perfect for spins – not too slippery, but not so rough that it will catch our feet." Her practical assessment reminded Klaus of his own military habit of surveying terrain and conditions before any operation. Perhaps his tactical mindset could be useful here after all, if applied correctly. The thought gave him a small measure of comfort.

They found a quiet corner where they could warm up and run through their routines one final time. As Klaus removed his jacket and began the stretching exercises Frau Steinberg had taught him, he watched the other competitors preparing around the room. The diversity was remarkable – couples ranging in age from barely out of their teens to well into their sixties, representing what seemed to be every social class and profession in the city. Dancing, Klaus realized, was perhaps one of the few activities that truly brought together people who might never otherwise occupy the same space.The warm-up session with Greta began with simple movements, their bodies finding the familiar rhythm they'd developed over months of practice together. Klaus led her through a basic waltz sequence, his military-trained muscle memory helping him maintain proper posture even as his mind raced with anticipation. Their feet moved across the small section of floor they'd claimed as their own, weaving between other couples who were engaged in similar preparations. The cacophony of different musical pieces being hummed or counted out loud created a strange symphony of anticipation that filled the grand ballroom.

As they moved through their routine, Klaus found himself studying Greta's face, searching for any sign of the nervousness that seemed to consume him. Her expression remained serene, focused but not tense, as if she were simply enjoying another practice session rather than preparing for the most important dance competition either of them had ever entered. This calm confidence had always been one of her most attractive qualities, though Klaus had never quite understood how she managed it. In his world, high-stakes situations demanded visible preparation, obvious signs of readiness and determination. Greta's approach was different – she prepared thoroughly but wore her preparation lightly, like a well-tailored dress that fit so perfectly it seemed effortless.

"Your leading has improved so much since we started," she commented as they paused between sequences, slightly breathless but still smiling. "Remember that first lesson when you kept trying to steer me like a military vehicle? Frau Steinberg thought she might have to give up on you entirely." Her laugh was gentle, teasing rather than mocking, and Klaus found himself smiling despite his nerves. The memory she'd referenced was both embarrassing and oddly precious now – his complete confusion at the concept of leading through subtle pressure and suggestion rather than direct commands had led to several minor collisions and one particularly spectacular stumble that had sent them both tumbling onto Frau Steinberg's sofa.

The transformation from those early, awkward sessions to their current level of partnership still amazed Klaus when he allowed himself to think about it objectively. Dancing had taught him things about communication and cooperation that years of military training had never touched. In combat, orders were given and followed, hierarchy was clear, and success was measured in concrete, quantifiable terms. Dancing required something more subtle – a conversation conducted through touch and movement, where both partners had to be simultaneously leader and follower, strong and yielding, confident and responsive to the other's needs.

A sudden commotion near the judges' platform drew their attention. The competition officials were beginning to set up their scoring tables and arrange their materials, their presence making the event feel suddenly, undeniably real. Klaus recognized Herr Brennan, the head judge, from the preliminary competition – a distinguished man in his sixties whose own competitive career had been legendary before he'd transitioned to judging. The other judges were less familiar to Klaus, but their serious demeanor and obvious expertise were intimidating enough. These were people who had dedicated their lives to the art of dance, who could spot technical flaws and missed opportunities that would be invisible to casual observers.

"They look so serious," Klaus murmured, unable to keep a note of concern from his voice. The judges moved with the careful precision of experts, arranging their papers and testing their pens with the same methodical attention to detail that Klaus might have applied to checking his equipment before a mission. The parallel was somehow both comforting and unnerving – familiar in its thoroughness, but alien in its application to something as seemingly joyful as dancing.

Greta followed his gaze and shrugged with characteristic nonchalance. "They have to look serious – it's their job. But I heard from one of the other competitors that Herr Brennan still tears up every time he watches a particularly beautiful waltz. He may look stern, but he loves this as much as any of us do." Her words were intended to reassure, and Klaus appreciated the effort, but the sight of the judging panel continued to make him acutely aware of everything that could go wrong during their performance. A missed step, poor timing, a stumble that broke the flow of their routine – any of these could end their chances before they'd really begun.

The orchestra began tuning their instruments, the discordant sounds of individual musicians preparing their parts gradually giving way to more organized warm-up pieces. Klaus had never danced to live music before – all of his lessons had been accompanied by Frau Steinberg's old gramophone or her own piano playing. The richness and complexity of a full orchestra was both thrilling and slightly overwhelming, adding another variable to an already complicated situation. He would need to adjust his timing, his sense of rhythm, to accommodate the subtle variations that live musicians inevitably brought to even the most familiar pieces.

As if reading his thoughts, Greta squeezed his hand gently. "Listen to how beautiful that sounds," she said, her eyes closed as she absorbed the musical preparation happening around them. "This is what we've been working toward, Klaus. Not the competition or the judges or the ribbons – this. The chance to dance to music like that, in a room like this, with all these people who love dancing as much as we do." Her perspective, as always, helped him refocus on what truly mattered. Somewhere in his anxiety about winning and losing, about proving himself and avoiding embarrassment, he'd lost sight of the simple joy that had drawn him to dancing in the first place.

The memory of that first accidental encounter with Studio Harmony returned to him with sudden clarity. He'd been walking back to base after a particularly difficult day of training exercises, his mind occupied with tactical problems and personnel issues, when the sound of music had drifted out onto the street through an open window. Something about the melody had made him pause, then step closer to investigate. Through the window, he'd watched couples moving across a small dance floor with what seemed like impossible grace and coordination, their movements telling stories that needed no words. For perhaps the first time in his adult life, Klaus had witnessed something that was purely beautiful, entirely removed from the practical considerations and strategic thinking that dominated his daily existence.

Standing now in the Grand Ballroom of the Kaiserhof Hotel, surrounded by the controlled chaos of competition preparation, Klaus tried to recapture that sense of wonder and discovery. The couples around them were no longer intimidating rivals but fellow travelers, people who had all been drawn to dancing by the same mysterious attraction that had pulled him through the doors of Frau Steinberg's studio. The judges were not adversaries but guardians of an art form, people whose expertise allowed them to recognize and celebrate excellence when they saw it. Even the elaborate setting, which had initially made him feel small and out of place, was simply a beautiful stage where ordinary people could become something extraordinary for the span of a few magical minutes.**Chapter 2: The First Dance**

The announcement came at precisely ten o'clock, delivered by a competition official whose voice carried easily across the vast ballroom despite the nervous chatter of competitors and spectators. "Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the Frankfurt Municipal Dance Competition. We will begin with the waltz, followed by the foxtrot, tango, and concluding with the quickstep. Couples will be called in groups of five, with each group performing for approximately four minutes before the next group takes the floor." Klaus felt his mouth go dry as the reality of performing settled over him like a lead blanket. Four minutes had never seemed like such an eternity, yet simultaneously felt impossibly brief to demonstrate months of preparation and practice.

The first group of couples took their positions on the gleaming parquet floor, their movements confident and fluid as they arranged themselves across the available space. Klaus recognized the elderly couple from Munich whose preliminary performance had been flawless, their decades of partnership evident in the way they moved together without seeming to communicate at all. Beside them, a young pair from Cologne adjusted their posture with the precision of dancers who had clearly trained in formal ballet before transitioning to ballroom. The contrast between natural partnership and technical training was fascinating to observe, and Klaus found himself wondering which approach would ultimately prove more successful in competition.

When the orchestra began the opening strains of a Strauss waltz, the transformation was immediate and breathtaking. The five couples moved as one organism across the floor, their individual styles blending into a tapestry of movement that seemed to bring the music to visual life. Klaus watched with the intensity he usually reserved for studying enemy positions, analyzing each couple's technique while simultaneously trying to calm his own racing heartbeat. The elderly couple moved with understated elegance, their steps economical but perfectly placed, while the young dancers from Cologne displayed technical virtuosity that drew admiring murmurs from the watching crowd. A middle-aged pair from Frankfurt itself danced with passionate intensity, their connection so obvious that Klaus found himself moved despite his analytical focus.

"They're all so different," Greta whispered beside him, her own eyes tracking the dancers with professional interest. "Look how the couple in blue stays close to the center while the others use the entire floor. And see how differently they interpret the same music? It's like watching five different conversations happening at once." Her observation helped Klaus shift his perspective from competitive analysis to artistic appreciation, though the knot in his stomach remained unchanged. The diversity of approaches was both encouraging and terrifying – it suggested there was no single correct way to dance, but also meant the judging criteria might be more subjective than he'd hoped.

The judges sat motionless at their elevated table, their expressions unreadable as they made notes on scorecards that would ultimately determine which couples advanced to the final round. Klaus tried to read their body language for clues about their preferences, searching for any indication of which performances were resonating most strongly. Herr Brennan's face remained perfectly neutral, though Klaus noticed he leaned forward slightly during the elderly couple's most intricate sequence. Another judge, a woman Klaus didn't recognize, tapped her pen rhythmically against her scorecard, apparently keeping time with the music in a way that suggested deep engagement with the performances.

When the first group concluded their waltz, the applause was enthusiastic but restrained, the kind of polite appreciation that acknowledged skill without revealing the audience's favorites. The dancers left the floor with varying degrees of satisfaction visible on their faces – some clearly pleased with their performance, others already analyzing what they might have done differently. Klaus felt a surge of empathy for all of them, these people who had exposed themselves to judgment in pursuit of something beautiful and ephemeral. The courage required to step onto that floor, to make oneself vulnerable to critique and comparison, was perhaps not so different from the bravery demanded in combat, though the stakes and consequences were entirely different.

The second group took their positions, and Klaus realized with a start that he recognized one of the men from his preliminary round. Herr Weber, a postal clerk whose gentle manner had made him seem almost invisible during the earlier competition, now commanded attention through his partnership with a woman Klaus hadn't seen before. Their practice clothes suggested serious preparation, and when they assumed their opening position, something in their bearing indicated they were ready to surprise the judges and audience alike. Klaus found himself silently rooting for the quiet postal clerk, perhaps seeing something of his own unlikely journey reflected in Weber's transformation from ordinary civil servant to serious dancer.

This group's interpretation of the waltz was markedly different from the first, with more dramatic use of the ballroom's space and greater emphasis on theatrical presentation. One couple incorporated lifts and dips that bordered on exhibition-style dancing, pushing the boundaries of traditional ballroom technique in ways that were either brilliant or foolhardy depending on one's perspective. The audience responded with more obvious enthusiasm, though Klaus noticed some of the judges exchanging glances that might have indicated concern about departing from classical standards. The tension between innovation and tradition was apparently as relevant in competitive dancing as it was in military strategy, where new tactics had to be balanced against proven methods.

Herr Weber and his partner surprised everyone, including Klaus, with a performance that combined technical precision with genuine emotional expression. The postal clerk's gentle manner translated into dancing of remarkable sensitivity, his leading so subtle and responsive that his partner seemed to float across the floor without effort. Klaus found himself leaning forward, caught up in the beauty of their movement despite his own anxiety about the approaching performance. There was something particularly moving about watching ordinary people transcend their daily limitations through art, becoming more than themselves through the simple act of moving together to music.

As the second group concluded their waltz, Klaus noticed that his own nervousness had been temporarily displaced by genuine appreciation for what he was witnessing. The level of skill and artistry displayed by these amateur dancers was far higher than he'd expected, challenging his assumptions about what could be achieved through dedication and practice rather than professional training. Each couple brought something unique to the same fundamental steps and musical structure, proving that technical competence was only the foundation for something larger and more meaningful. The realization was both inspiring and intimidating – inspiring because it suggested that he and Greta might also find their own unique voice within the established framework, intimidating because it raised the bar for what constituted a truly memorable performance.

The third group included the striking young couple from Munich whose tango had dominated the preliminary competition. Klaus watched them prepare with the focused intensity of seasoned competitors, their warm-up movements suggesting both technical excellence and natural chemistry. Their confidence was evident but not arrogant, the kind of quiet assurance that came from thorough preparation combined with genuine talent. Klaus admired their composure while simultaneously feeling intimidated by the standard they represented. These were dancers who belonged in this setting, who seemed born to perform on stages like the Kaiserhof ballroom.

When their waltz began, it was immediately clear why they had impressed the preliminary judges so thoroughly. Their movement was fluid yet precise, classical yet personal, demonstrating mastery of technique while maintaining the emotional connection that separated true artistry from mere technical display. The woman's dress moved like water as she spun, her partner's leading so assured that she appeared to anticipate his intentions before he'd fully formed them himself. Klaus found himself studying their partnership with professional admiration, trying to understand how they achieved such seamless communication through nothing more than touch and shared rhythm.

The audience's response was notably stronger for this group, with several spectators leaning forward in their chairs and the polite applause giving way to something approaching genuine excitement. Klaus noticed that even the judges seemed more engaged, their note-taking more frequent and their attention more focused. The competitive landscape was becoming clear – there were several couples who belonged in a different category from the others, dancers whose skill level and experience placed them among the genuine contenders for the championship. The question was whether he and Greta could possibly compete at that level, or whether they were destined to be admirable participants rather than serious competitors.

"Couple number sixteen, please prepare for the next group," the official announced, and Klaus felt his heart stop. Sixteen was their number, pinned to his back like a target that suddenly felt far too visible. The moment he had been anticipating and dreading in equal measure had finally arrived, and all the preparation and practice in the world couldn't change the fact that the next few minutes would determine whether their unlikely journey continued or ended in disappointment. Greta squeezed his hand as they stood, her touch steady and reassuring even as Klaus felt his own fingers trembling slightly with nervous energy that refused to be suppressed despite his best efforts at military-style mental discipline.**Chapter 3: Under the Lights**

As Klaus and Greta approached the dance floor with the other couples in their group, the ballroom seemed to transform around them, becoming simultaneously larger and smaller than it had appeared from the sidelines. The polished parquet stretched endlessly in every direction, offering vast space for movement while also feeling intimate under the warm glow of the chandeliers that cast intricate patterns of light and shadow across the surface. Klaus could hear his own heartbeat drumming against his ribs, a rhythm that seemed entirely disconnected from the gentle musical preparations of the orchestra, and he struggled to reconcile the two competing tempos that threatened to throw off his carefully practiced timing. The faces of the spectators blurred into an indistinct sea of expectation, their presence both encouraging and overwhelming as Klaus realized that hundreds of people were about to watch him attempt something he had never imagined himself capable of just months earlier.

Greta moved beside him with her characteristic grace, her hand resting lightly in his as they found their starting position near the center of the floor. Her presence anchored him in a way that felt familiar from their countless practice sessions, yet the context made everything feel new and uncertain again, as if he were learning to dance for the first time rather than drawing upon months of careful preparation and gradually building confidence. The other couples in their group arranged themselves around the available space with the practiced efficiency of people accustomed to sharing performance areas, each pair claiming their territory through subtle positioning that respected the others while maximizing their own opportunities for impressive sequences and dramatic use of the floor. Klaus found himself admiring their easy confidence even as he envied it, wondering if he would ever feel truly at home in this world of artistic competition and public performance that seemed so natural to some people and so foreign to his military-trained sensibilities.

The orchestra conductor raised his baton, and Klaus felt time slow in the peculiar way it always did before moments of high stress and potential danger. His military experience had taught him to recognize this sensation, the way consciousness seemed to expand and sharpen when everything important hung in the balance, but applying that familiar psychological response to dancing felt surreal and slightly absurd even as he was grateful for any advantage his background might provide. The opening notes of the waltz filled the ballroom with rich, layered sound that seemed to emanate from everywhere at once, the live music creating an atmosphere of grandeur and sophistication that no gramophone or piano could possibly match. Klaus took his first step, feeling Greta respond immediately to his lead, and suddenly they were dancing together in the most beautiful room either of them had ever seen, surrounded by an audience that had chosen to spend their morning watching ordinary people attempt to create something extraordinary through the simple act of moving together to music.

The first minute of their performance felt like pure instinct, their bodies remembering the countless hours they had spent learning to move as one unit, practicing until the basic steps became automatic and they could focus on the subtler elements of expression and artistry that separated competent dancing from truly memorable performance. Klaus found himself relaxing into the familiar rhythm of leading Greta through sequences they had rehearsed dozens of times, his confidence growing as he realized that the months of preparation had created muscle memory strong enough to withstand the pressure of competition and public scrutiny. Greta followed his lead with the same intuitive responsiveness she had always shown, her trust in his guidance allowing him to attempt more ambitious movements than he might have dared with a less compatible partner. Together they moved through their carefully choreographed routine while simultaneously responding to the music and the moment, finding the balance between planned precision and spontaneous expression that Frau Steinberg had always insisted was the hallmark of truly accomplished social dancing.

The awareness of being watched, judged, and evaluated gradually faded as Klaus lost himself in the pure physical pleasure of dancing well with someone whose movement complemented his own so perfectly. This was what he had been searching for without knowing it during all those years of military service, this sense of partnership that transcended individual capability and created something greater than either person could achieve alone. The realization struck him with unexpected force as they moved through a particularly complex sequence of turns and promenades, their timing so synchronized that Klaus felt as if they were sharing the same heartbeat, the same breath, the same understanding of what the music demanded from their bodies and their partnership. He had experienced similar moments of perfect coordination during combat operations, when his unit functioned as a single organism responding to threats and opportunities with collective intelligence, but this was different, more joyful and creative, focused on beauty rather than survival, on expression rather than destruction.

The second minute of their waltz brought increasing confidence and ambition as Klaus realized they were dancing better than they ever had before, their partnership enhanced rather than hindered by the formal setting and public attention that had initially seemed so intimidating. The acoustics of the grand ballroom carried the orchestra's music with crystalline clarity that made it easier to feel the subtle rhythmic variations and melodic nuances that informed their movement, while the excellent floor surface allowed for spins and glides that would have been impossible on the smaller, less perfect surfaces where they had practiced. Klaus began to understand why serious dancers sought out venues like this, why the setting mattered as much as the skill of the performers, and why dancing in the Kaiserhof ballroom felt like the culmination of everything they had worked toward rather than simply another practice session with an audience attached. The room itself seemed to inspire better dancing, its grandeur calling forth a level of elegance and sophistication that matched its own architectural magnificence.

Greta's eyes met his during a moment of close positioning, and Klaus saw in her expression the same wonder and exhilaration he was feeling, the shared recognition that they were experiencing something special and unrepeatable that would remain with them long after the competition ended and the scores were announced. Her smile was radiant with pure joy, free from the anxiety and self-consciousness that had marked their earlier practice sessions, and Klaus realized that somewhere during their performance they had both stopped worrying about winning or losing and started simply celebrating the opportunity to dance together in such extraordinary circumstances. This transformation from nervous competitors to joyful performers was perhaps the greatest victory they could achieve, regardless of how the judges ultimately scored their technical execution and artistic interpretation. They had found what Frau Steinberg had always promised was possible for those willing to trust in the music and in each other – the transcendent experience of becoming more than themselves through the shared language of dance.

The third minute brought their most challenging sequence, a series of rapid rotations and directional changes that had given them trouble during practice sessions and required absolute trust between partners to execute successfully. Klaus felt his military training assert itself as he approached these difficult passages, his tactical mind automatically breaking down the complex movements into manageable components while his body relied on trained reflexes to maintain proper timing and positioning. The morning sun cast long shadows across the cobblestone streets of Frankfurt's old quarter as Klaus Zimmermann adjusted his military dress uniform for what felt like the hundredth time. His calloused hands, more accustomed to gripping a rifle than smoothing fabric, trembled slightly as he straightened the crisp collar. Today was different from any other day in his twenty-eight years of life, different from the countless mornings he'd spent in barracks or on patrol. Today, Klaus would dance.

"Mein Gott, you look like you're about to face a firing squad rather than a ballroom," chuckled his roommate Heinrich from across their modest apartment. Heinrich was sprawled carelessly across his unmade bed, still in yesterday's clothes, a half-empty bottle of beer dangling from his fingers despite the early hour. The contrast between the two men couldn't have been starker – Klaus, immaculate and nervous, Heinrich, disheveled and perpetually relaxed.

"It feels almost the same," Klaus replied, his voice carrying the slight rasp that came from years of shouting orders across training grounds. He moved to the small mirror hanging crooked on the wall, a relic from the apartment's previous tenant. The reflection that stared back at him was familiar yet somehow foreign. The same angular jawline, the same steel-gray eyes that had seen too much during his tours of duty, but there was something else there now – hope, perhaps, or maybe just barely contained terror.

Heinrich rolled his eyes and took another swig of beer. "You do realize this is supposed to be fun, yes? Dancing, music, pretty women in sparkly dresses? Not exactly a combat mission." He paused, studying his friend's rigid posture. "When was the last time you did something just because it made you happy?"

The question hung in the air like smoke from Heinrich's ever-present cigarettes. Klaus couldn't remember the last time he'd done anything purely for joy. His life had been structured, regimented, purposeful in the way military life demanded. Wake at five, physical training at six, duties until evening, sleep by ten. Repeat. The dancing lessons had started almost by accident – a wrong turn down a Frankfurt street three months ago had led him past Studio Harmony, where Frau Elisabeth Steinberg taught ballroom dancing to anyone brave enough to step through her doors.

"I should have practiced the foxtrot more," Klaus muttered, ignoring Heinrich's philosophical question. He began pacing the small confines of their living room, his polished boots clicking rhythmically against the worn wooden floors. "The judges will be watching every step, every turn. One mistake and—"

"And what?" Heinrich interrupted, sitting up with more energy than he'd shown all morning. "The world ends? You get court-martialed for poor heel-toe technique?" He shook his head in amazement. "Klaus, my friend, you've survived three deployments, earned two commendations for bravery, and you're worried about dancing?"

But Klaus wasn't listening anymore. His mind had drifted to the letter he'd received two weeks prior, the letter that had changed everything. The Frankfurt Municipal Dance Competition Committee had written to inform him that he'd been selected as one of twenty finalists for their annual championship. Twenty finalists from over three hundred applicants. The letter was carefully folded in his breast pocket now, read and reread so many times the creases had become permanent.

The selection had shocked everyone, including Klaus himself. He'd entered the preliminary competition on a whim, encouraged by Frau Steinberg who insisted he had "natural rhythm hiding beneath all that military stiffness." She'd been teaching him for only two months when the preliminaries were announced, hardly enough time to master anything beyond the basic steps. Yet somehow, dancing with Greta Müller, a secretary from the mayor's office who'd become his regular partner, he'd managed to impress the judges enough to advance.

"She'll be there today," Klaus said suddenly, stopping his pacing to look out the window toward the city center where the competition would be held.

"Who? Greta?" Heinrich asked, though he already knew the answer. Klaus had talked about little else for weeks. Greta with her auburn hair that caught the light when she spun. Greta with her patient smile when he stumbled through a difficult sequence. Greta who somehow made the regimented soldier feel graceful, almost elegant.

"She's been so patient with me," Klaus continued, his voice softening. "Never complains when I step on her feet, never laughs when I lose count of the music. She says I'm getting better, but..." He trailed off, uncertainty creeping back into his voice.

Heinrich stood and walked over to his friend, placing a hand on his shoulder. "But nothing. You earned your place in that final fair and square. Stop acting like you don't deserve to be there." He paused, studying Klaus's profile as he continued staring out the window. "You know what your problem is? You think everything has to be perfect, that you have to be the best at everything you try. Sometimes it's okay to just... be."

The words struck something deep in Klaus's chest, though he couldn't quite identify what. All his life had been about excelling, about meeting standards and exceeding expectations. In the military, mediocrity could mean death – for himself or his men. But dancing? Dancing was supposed to be different, wasn't it? Yet here he was, treating it like another mission to complete, another objective to achieve.

A church bell chimed in the distance, and Klaus felt his stomach lurch. "I should go," he said, though his feet seemed rooted to the floor. "The competition starts in two hours, and I promised Greta I'd meet her early for a final practice session."

"Go then," Heinrich said, returning to his bed and his beer. "And Klaus? Try to smile out there. You're allowed to enjoy this."

Klaus nodded, grabbed his jacket, and headed for the door. As his hand touched the handle, Heinrich called out once more: "Whatever happens today, you're still the same man who pulled three wounded soldiers to safety under enemy fire. A dancing competition should be easy compared to that."

But as Klaus stepped into the morning sunlight and began walking toward the city center, he wasn't so sure. Combat he understood – there were rules, tactics, clear objectives. Dancing felt like stepping into uncharted territory, where success couldn't be measured in tactical victories or completed missions. It was messier, more uncertain, more human.

The streets of Frankfurt were already bustling with early morning activity. Shopkeepers swept their storefronts, early commuters hurried past with newspapers tucked under their arms, and somewhere in the distance, Klaus could hear the faint sound of music drifting from an open window. The city felt alive in a way he rarely noticed during his usual routine of base duties and military obligations.

As he walked, Klaus found himself thinking about the path that had led him to this moment. Three months ago, he'd been a soldier and nothing more. His identity was wrapped up entirely in his rank, his duties, his service record. Now, incredibly, he was also a dancer – or at least someone who danced. The transformation felt both thrilling and terrifying.

The studio where he'd first met Frau Steinberg came into view, its windows still dark at this early hour. But Klaus could picture it as it would be later in the day, filled with couples moving in perfect synchronization, the sound of feet gliding across polished floors, the gentle guidance of Frau Steinberg's voice calling out instructions and encouragement.

She had been the one to suggest he enter the preliminary competition, despite his protests that he wasn't ready. "Readiness is a luxury," she'd said in her matter-of-fact way. "Sometimes you must simply begin." At the time, he'd thought she was talking about dancing. Now he wondered if she'd meant something else entirely.

The venue for the Frankfurt Municipal Dance Competition was the Grand Ballroom of the Kaiserhof Hotel, a magnificent space that Klaus had only glimpsed from the street during his years stationed in the city. As he approached the imposing limestone facade, with its ornate carvings and tall windows that reflected the morning light like mirrors, he felt his breath catch in his throat. The building seemed to dwarf him, its grandeur a stark reminder of how far he'd traveled from his humble beginnings in a small Bavarian village where the grandest social event had been the annual harvest festival in the local church hall.

Couples were already arriving, their practice bags slung over shoulders, some stretching against the hotel's exterior walls while others ran through quick sequences on the sidewalk. Klaus recognized several faces from the preliminary rounds – there was Herr Mueller, a bank manager who danced with his wife of thirty years, their movements so synchronized they seemed to share a single heartbeat. Near the entrance, he spotted the young couple from Munich whose tango had left the preliminary judges speechless, their dark hair and matching black practice outfits making them look like professional performers rather than amateur competitors.

The sight of such seasoned pairs made Klaus's confidence waver again. These people had clearly been dancing together for years, their partnerships refined through countless hours of practice and performance. What was he doing here, a soldier who had learned to waltz only months ago, presuming to compete against such established talent? His hands found the letter in his breast pocket again, touching it as if to reassure himself that his invitation wasn't some elaborate mistake or cruel joke.

"Klaus! There you are!" The familiar voice cut through his spiraling doubts like a lifeline. Greta emerged from the hotel's revolving door, her auburn hair pinned up in an elegant chignon that made her neck look impossibly graceful. She wore a simple blue dress that would later be replaced by their competition gown, but even in practice clothes, she moved with the fluid confidence that had first caught his attention in Frau Steinberg's studio. Her smile was warm and genuine, free from the nervous energy that seemed to radiate from every other competitor in sight.

"You look like you're planning a military strategy rather than preparing for a dance," she teased gently, falling into step beside him as they walked toward the hotel entrance. Her presence immediately steadied him, the way it always did. There was something about Greta that made the world feel more manageable, less overwhelming. Perhaps it was her background as a secretary – she was accustomed to bringing order to chaos, to finding solutions for seemingly impossible problems. Or perhaps it was simply her nature, calm and assured where he was anxious and uncertain.

The hotel lobby was a marvel of marble and crystal, with soaring ceilings decorated in gold leaf and a chandelier that cast rainbow fragments across the polished floors. Klaus had to consciously prevent himself from gawking like a tourist as they made their way toward the ballroom. The wealth displayed here so casually was more than his family had seen in their entire lives, more luxury than existed in all the barracks where he'd spent the better part of a decade. He felt simultaneously grateful for the opportunity to experience such grandeur and acutely aware of how out of place he was in this rarefied world.

Other competitors filled the lobby, their conversations creating a low buzz of excitement and nervous energy. Klaus caught fragments of discussion about technique and strategy, about judges' preferences and scoring systems. The level of sophistication in these conversations made him realize how much he still didn't know about the world of competitive dancing. He and Greta had focused on learning the steps, mastering the basic techniques, but these people spoke of dancing as if it were a science, with theories and methodologies that went far beyond simple choreography.

"Stop overthinking," Greta whispered, apparently reading his expression as easily as she might read one of the reports that crossed her desk at city hall. "Remember what Frau Steinberg always tells us – dancing is feeling first, thinking second. All those people talking strategy? Half of them will forget everything they've planned the moment the music starts." Her hand brushed against his arm reassuringly, and Klaus felt some of the tension leave his shoulders.

The ballroom itself was even more magnificent than Klaus had imagined. The ceiling soared at least thirty feet above the polished parquet floor, supported by columns wrapped in gold leaf that caught and reflected the light from three massive chandeliers. Tall windows lined one wall, offering glimpses of Frankfurt's skyline, while the opposite wall featured ornate mirrors that made the already enormous space seem infinite. A raised platform at one end of the room held chairs for the judges, while another platform accommodated the orchestra that would provide live music for the competition.

Tables and chairs had been arranged around the perimeter of the dance floor for spectators, and Klaus was surprised to see that many were already occupied despite the early hour. He recognized some faces from the preliminary competition – family members, friends, and what appeared to be serious dance enthusiasts who attended such events regularly. The sight of the audience made his stomach clench again. Dancing with Greta in the relative privacy of Frau Steinberg's studio was one thing; performing in front of hundreds of strangers was something else entirely.

"The floor is beautiful," Greta observed, kneeling to run her hand across the smooth parquet. "Perfect for spins – not too slippery, but not so rough that it will catch our feet." Her practical assessment reminded Klaus of his own military habit of surveying terrain and conditions before any operation. Perhaps his tactical mindset could be useful here after all, if applied correctly. The thought gave him a small measure of comfort.

They found a quiet corner where they could warm up and run through their routines one final time. As Klaus removed his jacket and began the stretching exercises Frau Steinberg had taught him, he watched the other competitors preparing around the room. The diversity was remarkable – couples ranging in age from barely out of their teens to well into their sixties, representing what seemed to be every social class and profession in the city. Dancing, Klaus realized, was perhaps one of the few activities that truly brought together people who might never otherwise occupy the same space.

The warm-up session with Greta began with simple movements, their bodies finding the familiar rhythm they'd developed over months of practice together. Klaus led her through a basic waltz sequence, his military-trained muscle memory helping him maintain proper posture even as his mind raced with anticipation. Their feet moved across the small section of floor they'd claimed as their own, weaving between other couples who were engaged in similar preparations. The cacophony of different musical pieces being hummed or counted out loud created a strange symphony of anticipation that filled the grand ballroom.

As they moved through their routine, Klaus found himself studying Greta's face, searching for any sign of the nervousness that seemed to consume him. Her expression remained serene, focused but not tense, as if she were simply enjoying another practice session rather than preparing for the most important dance competition either of them had ever entered. This calm confidence had always been one of her most attractive qualities, though Klaus had never quite understood how she managed it. In his world, high-stakes situations demanded visible preparation, obvious signs of readiness and determination. Greta's approach was different – she prepared thoroughly but wore her preparation lightly, like a well-tailored dress that fit so perfectly it seemed effortless.

"Your leading has improved so much since we started," she commented as they paused between sequences, slightly breathless but still smiling. "Remember that first lesson when you kept trying to steer me like a military vehicle? Frau Steinberg thought she might have to give up on you entirely." Her laugh was gentle, teasing rather than mocking, and Klaus found himself smiling despite his nerves. The memory she'd referenced was both embarrassing and oddly precious now – his complete confusion at the concept of leading through subtle pressure and suggestion rather than direct commands had led to several minor collisions and one particularly spectacular stumble that had sent them both tumbling onto Frau Steinberg's sofa.

The transformation from those early, awkward sessions to their current level of partnership still amazed Klaus when he allowed himself to think about it objectively. Dancing had taught him things about communication and cooperation that years of military training had never touched. In combat, orders were given and followed, hierarchy was clear, and success was measured in concrete, quantifiable terms. Dancing required something more subtle – a conversation conducted through touch and movement, where both partners had to be simultaneously leader and follower, strong and yielding, confident and responsive to the other's needs.

A sudden commotion near the judges' platform drew their attention. The competition officials were beginning to set up their scoring tables and arrange their materials, their presence making the event feel suddenly, undeniably real. Klaus recognized Herr Brennan, the head judge, from the preliminary competition – a distinguished man in his sixties whose own competitive career had been legendary before he'd transitioned to judging. The other judges were less familiar to Klaus, but their serious demeanor and obvious expertise were intimidating enough. These were people who had dedicated their lives to the art of dance, who could spot technical flaws and missed opportunities that would be invisible to casual observers.

"They look so serious," Klaus murmured, unable to keep a note of concern from his voice. The judges moved with the careful precision of experts, arranging their papers and testing their pens with the same methodical attention to detail that Klaus might have applied to checking his equipment before a mission. The parallel was somehow both comforting and unnerving – familiar in its thoroughness, but alien in its application to something as seemingly joyful as dancing.

Greta followed his gaze and shrugged with characteristic nonchalance. "They have to look serious – it's their job. But I heard from one of the other competitors that Herr Brennan still tears up every time he watches a particularly beautiful waltz. He may look stern, but he loves this as much as any of us do." Her words were intended to reassure, and Klaus appreciated the effort, but the sight of the judging panel continued to make him acutely aware of everything that could go wrong during their performance. A missed step, poor timing, a stumble that broke the flow of their routine – any of these could end their chances before they'd really begun.

The orchestra began tuning their instruments, the discordant sounds of individual musicians preparing their parts gradually giving way to more organized warm-up pieces. Klaus had never danced to live music before – all of his lessons had been accompanied by Frau Steinberg's old gramophone or her own piano playing. The richness and complexity of a full orchestra was both thrilling and slightly overwhelming, adding another variable to an already complicated situation. He would need to adjust his timing, his sense of rhythm, to accommodate the subtle variations that live musicians inevitably brought to even the most familiar pieces.

As if reading his thoughts, Greta squeezed his hand gently. "Listen to how beautiful that sounds," she said, her eyes closed as she absorbed the musical preparation happening around them. "This is what we've been working toward, Klaus. Not the competition or the judges or the ribbons – this. The chance to dance to music like that, in a room like this, with all these people who love dancing as much as we do." Her perspective, as always, helped him refocus on what truly mattered. Somewhere in his anxiety about winning and losing, about proving himself and avoiding embarrassment, he'd lost sight of the simple joy that had drawn him to dancing in the first place.

The memory of that first accidental encounter with Studio Harmony returned to him with sudden clarity. He'd been walking back to base after a particularly difficult day of training exercises, his mind occupied with tactical problems and personnel issues, when the sound of music had drifted out onto the street through an open window. Something about the melody had made him pause, then step closer to investigate. Through the window, he'd watched couples moving across a small dance floor with what seemed like impossible grace and coordination, their movements telling stories that needed no words. For perhaps the first time in his adult life, Klaus had witnessed something that was purely beautiful, entirely removed from the practical considerations and strategic thinking that dominated his daily existence.

Standing now in the Grand Ballroom of the Kaiserhof Hotel, surrounded by the controlled chaos of competition preparation, Klaus tried to recapture that sense of wonder and discovery. The couples around them were no longer intimidating rivals but fellow travelers, people who had all been drawn to dancing by the same mysterious attraction that had pulled him through the doors of Frau Steinberg's studio. The judges were not adversaries but guardians of an art form, people whose expertise allowed them to recognize and celebrate excellence when they saw it. Even the elaborate setting, which had initially made him feel small and out of place, was simply a beautiful stage where ordinary people could become something extraordinary for the span of a few magical minutes.

**Chapter 2: The First Dance**

The announcement came at precisely ten o'clock, delivered by a competition official whose voice carried easily across the vast ballroom despite the nervous chatter of competitors and spectators. "Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the Frankfurt Municipal Dance Competition. We will begin with the waltz, followed by the foxtrot, tango, and concluding with the quickstep. Couples will be called in groups of five, with each group performing for approximately four minutes before the next group takes the floor." Klaus felt his mouth go dry as the reality of performing settled over him like a lead blanket. Four minutes had never seemed like such an eternity, yet simultaneously felt impossibly brief to demonstrate months of preparation and practice.

The first group of couples took their positions on the gleaming parquet floor, their movements confident and fluid as they arranged themselves across the available space. Klaus recognized the elderly couple from Munich whose preliminary performance had been flawless, their decades of partnership evident in the way they moved together without seeming to communicate at all. Beside them, a young pair from Cologne adjusted their posture with the precision of dancers who had clearly trained in formal ballet before transitioning to ballroom. The contrast between natural partnership and technical training was fascinating to observe, and Klaus found himself wondering which approach would ultimately prove more successful in competition.

When the orchestra began the opening strains of a Strauss waltz, the transformation was immediate and breathtaking. The five couples moved as one organism across the floor, their individual styles blending into a tapestry of movement that seemed to bring the music to visual life. Klaus watched with the intensity he usually reserved for studying enemy positions, analyzing each couple's technique while simultaneously trying to calm his own racing heartbeat. The elderly couple moved with understated elegance, their steps economical but perfectly placed, while the young dancers from Cologne displayed technical virtuosity that drew admiring murmurs from the watching crowd. A middle-aged pair from Frankfurt itself danced with passionate intensity, their connection so obvious that Klaus found himself moved despite his analytical focus.

"They're all so different," Greta whispered beside him, her own eyes tracking the dancers with professional interest. "Look how the couple in blue stays close to the center while the others use the entire floor. And see how differently they interpret the same music? It's like watching five different conversations happening at once." Her observation helped Klaus shift his perspective from competitive analysis to artistic appreciation, though the knot in his stomach remained unchanged. The diversity of approaches was both encouraging and terrifying – it suggested there was no single correct way to dance, but also meant the judging criteria might be more subjective than he'd hoped.

The judges sat motionless at their elevated table, their expressions unreadable as they made notes on scorecards that would ultimately determine which couples advanced to the final round. Klaus tried to read their body language for clues about their preferences, searching for any indication of which performances were resonating most strongly. Herr Brennan's face remained perfectly neutral, though Klaus noticed he leaned forward slightly during the elderly couple's most intricate sequence. Another judge, a woman Klaus didn't recognize, tapped her pen rhythmically against her scorecard, apparently keeping time with the music in a way that suggested deep engagement with the performances.

When the first group concluded their waltz, the applause was enthusiastic but restrained, the kind of polite appreciation that acknowledged skill without revealing the audience's favorites. The dancers left the floor with varying degrees of satisfaction visible on their faces – some clearly pleased with their performance, others already analyzing what they might have done differently. Klaus felt a surge of empathy for all of them, these people who had exposed themselves to judgment in pursuit of something beautiful and ephemeral.
